body.p: A Kentucky merchant, businessman, soldier, and politician. Received a common education. Married to Elizabeth Sarah “Sallie” Withers Bruce. Father of Mattie Withers Bruce Reynolds, George Stubblefield Bruce, and Charles Albert Withers Bruce. Worked as a clerk at a dry good store in Maysville, Kentucky in 1847. Worked in the pork-packing industry in the Cincinnati, Ohio with his uncle John S. Morgan. Owned several pork and beef packing plants along the Wabash, Missouri, and Mississippi rivers—based in St. Louis, Missouri and Chattanooga, Tennessee. Established and owned an iron furnace operation with his uncle Henry Bruce, Jr. in Terra Haute, Indiana in 1854. Served as a staff officer for John C. Breckinridge in the Confederate State Army during the Civil War. Served as a member of the Council of Ten in the Provisional Government of Kentucky. Served the Ninth Congressional District as a member of the Second Confederate Congress in the House of Representatives from 1862 to 1865. Appointed by Confederate Secretary of War James E. Seddon as acting commissary general of the Confederate States of America from January 30, 1865 to the end of the war. Moved to New York City, New York.
